parameters.name: Abkhazia
parameters.visa_comment:
You need to apply for a visa online:
https://mfaapsny.org/en/consular-service/permission/
After you get an authorization back (e-mail), you'll be able to cross the border, but then you'll need to get your visa at the consular service office in Sukhumi.
parameters.disputed: Breakaway Georgian republic only recognized by Russia and a few other states.
parameters.comment:
It used to be possible to enter from Georgian side, but apparently not anymore.
It's certainly possible to visit from Russia (with a multiple-entry Russian visa).

capital_translations.ja: アンドラ・ラ・ベリャ

parameters.comment: Exit tax: 15 AED pp.
parameters.name: United Arab Emirates
parameters.carnet_comment:
A carnet is required if you arrive by sea (from Iran, e.g.) or if you ship your vehicle by container or by air.
It is sometimes asked at the border, but usually not.
Before COVID, a carnet was not required.
parameters.comment: Since COVID, it's impossible to enter the country with a foreign vehicle. On the other hand, it's no problem to exit the country with your own vehicle, so one work-around if you want to visit Azerbaijan, is to ship your vehicle on the back of a truck into the country, then you're free to go wherever you want. It doesn't make much sense, but that's how it is.
parameters.name: Azerbaijan

parameters.carnet_comment: It seems that for a couple years you can now enter the country on a carnet.
parameters.name: Bangladesh

translations.ja: ボスニア・ヘルツェゴビナ
translations.zh: 波斯尼亚和黑塞哥维那

capital_translations.ja: バンダルスリブガワン

parameters.comment: One can enter only after having purchased a package from a travel agency at the minimum 200$/day
parameters.name: Bhutan

parameters.carnet_comment: No carnet, but many other permits are necessary anyway
parameters.comment: It's very difficult to get into China with their own vehicle, even for a short transit from Kyrgyzstan to Pakistan one must obtain many permits and authorizations and be accompanied by a guide, which is extremely costly.
parameters.name: China

parameters.comment: Most of the country is in ruined, the roads are missing in many provinces, except for the transit between Kinshasa and Matadi
parameters.name: Dem. Rep. Congo
Northern Cyprus

translations.ja: 北キプロス・トルコ共和国

parameters.disputed: De facto independent state, but recognized only by Turkey.

parameters.name: Algeria
parameters.comment: Most of the south is out of unstable security-wide, and one needs an army escort to explore the areas around Djanet and Tamanrasset.
This marxist country makes it very difficult to enter with their own vehicle.
parameters.name: Eritrea
Ethiopia
parameters.visa_comment: Visa on arrival available at the airport, but not at land borders.

parameters.disputed: Israel does not recognize Gaza as an independent state and maintains administrative control over the territory's borders.
parameters.name: Gaza

parameters.carnet_comment: In theory a carnet is mandatory, but in practice many overlanders have managed to get in paying only for a temporary import permit
parameters.name: Ghana
Indonesia
parameters.comment:
It's difficult to enter from Malaysia (mainland) or Singapore, only one shipping boat can bring motorbikes without too much fuss. 
It's much easier to enter overland from Timor or from the Borneo states of Malaysia.

parameters.carnet_comment: You can leave the vehicle in the country for a maximum of 180 days.
parameters.comment:
Note that special permits (free) are required for the following areas:
- Ladakh border areas
- Spiti
- Sikkim
- Arunachal Pradesh
parameters.name: India
parameters.visa_comment:
You can very easily get an e-visa online, or a "sticker" visa in an embassy.
Note that you can't enter India overland with an e-visa. It has to be processed at an airport immigration office to be accepted.
But it you have a multiple-entry e-visa, and you have entered the country by air, then you can later re-enter India at a land border, should you, e.g., visit Nepal and come back.
If you're coming into India overland, then you'll need to get your visa from an embassy, which will stick a visa into your passport.

parameters.name: Iran
parameters.visa_comment:
An eVisa is theoretically available but not very reliable. A visa is best secured via a travel agency, which will get an official confirmation from the ministry. With this confirmation, you can then walk into any embassy and buy your visa.
Note that citizens of the USA, UK, Canada and Australia can't travel on their own in Iran, they need a guide at all time.
The 30 days visa can be extended in most province capitals.
Some nationalities can enter visa-free. Israelis can't enter at all.
parameters.comment: Iran is open and a historically has always been a grzat tourist destination, with the caveat that some tourists have been arbitrarily arrested and detained on bogus charges of spying. That's the reason most countries recommend not to visit Iran.
parameters.carnet_comment: A carnet is required. There are ways to get a temporary, Iran-only carnet at the border, which is very expensive and not refundable. So a carnet is a must to enter with their own vehicle.
Exception: a carnet is not required if you enter and exit from Kurdistan. It is required if you cross any other border (Kuwait, Iran or Jordan).
parameters.name: Iraq

parameters.carnet_comment: No carnet, but the customs will write down your vehicle in your passport, which is then unusable in some arab countries
parameters.name: Israel
parameters.visa_comment: Watch for the israeli stamp in your passport, but also a jordanian entry stamp from a border post with Israel: you can be refused the entry in some arab countries

parameters.carnet_comment:
You can enter without a carnet and stay with your vehicle up to 1 month (TIP).
If your vehicle has a petrol engine, you can extend your TIP at the custom office at the border.
If your vehicle has a diesel engine and you want to stay longer than 1 month, you need a carnet and have it stamped at the border.
parameters.comment:
Insurance (bike): 27 JOD
Carnet stamp: 20 JOD
parameters.name: Jordan
Kazakhstan
parameters.visa_comment: Most European countries and a few others don't need a visa to enter Kazakhstan for up to 30 days.

parameters.name: Kenya
parameters.carnet_comment: Theoretically a carnet is needed, but it's always possible to get away without.

parameters.name: Kyrgyzstan
parameters.visa_comment: Visa free for most European nationals

parameters.capital: រាជធានីភ្នំពេញ
parameters.name: Cambodia

parameters.comment: 1. Compulsory insurance is expensive for a short visit 2. It's forbidden to cross into Serbia from Kosovo
parameters.name: Kosovo
Kuwait
parameters.visa_comment:
Most nationalities are eligible to an e-visa: https://kuwaitvisa.moi.gov.kw
You can also get it directly at the border, but it takes more time (same price). 
Price (2025): 3 KWD, valid for 90 days. 
It usually takes less than 1 hour to receive it online.
parameters.carnet_comment: The carnet is stamped if you show it at the proper person, but it's possible to enter without.
It seems it's possible to enter without carnet, by paying a tax/bribe. To be on the safe side, come with a carnet.
parameters.name: Lebanon
Libya
parameters.visa_comment: Visa are no longer granted, but anyway the government doesn't control the country anymore.

translations.ja: マケドニア(旧ユーゴスラビア共和国)
translations.zh: 马其顿（前南斯拉夫马其顿共和国）

parameters.comment: Anywhere north of the Niger is unsafe for travel.
parameters.name: Mali
parameters.visa_comment: Seems you can't get a visa at the border anymore.

parameters.capital: နေပြည်တော်
parameters.carnet_comment: No carnet, but other permits and an escort are required
parameters.comment:
Since the military takeover in 2021, overland travel has been impossible.
Before that, an overland travel from India to Thailand was possible with a guide and escort organized by an official travel agent.
parameters.name: Myanmar
Mongolia
parameters.visa_comment: (most) European nationals need no visa until end 2015, for a stay of up to 30 days.

parameters.carnet_comment: A carnet is required only if you're shipping into the country, it is not checked if you're entering from Thailand.
parameters.name: Malaysia

parameters.carnet_comment: A carnet is required only if you're shipping into the country, not when entering through a land border
parameters.name: Namibia

parameters.comment: The Sahara is closed off (unsafe).
parameters.name: Niger

parameters.comment: The northern half of the country is very unstable and not safe, as well as the Niger delta region.
parameters.name: Nigeria

parameters.carnet_comment: Exception: carnet is not required for vehicles registered in India.
parameters.name: Nepal
parameters.visa_comment:
Many nationalities can get an e-visa very easily online, but read below:
An e-visa is not valid for entry by land borders - unless it's a multi-entry e-visa, and you've "validated" it by entering a first time by air.
So if you plan on entering overland from Pakistan or Nepal, e.g., you need a normal, "sticker" visa, obtained in an embassy.

parameters.carnet_comment: A carnet is normally required, though you you can also apply for a permit and pay a cash deposit that you get back when you re-export the vehicle, but this is complicated and not recommended.
parameters.name: New Zealand

parameters.carnet_comment:
It is sometimes asked at the border, but usually not.
It is required when shipping into the country.
parameters.name: Oman
parameters.visa_comment:
Most nationalities are eligible to enter visa-free for 14 days (just a stamp in the passport at the" border). But this cannot be extended, you must get out of the country before the end of your 14 days. 
If you want to stay longer, you can apply for an e-visa (2025: 20 OMR : 20 days), which you can also extend for 30 more days (online as well):
https://evisa.rop.gov.om/
parameters.comment: Easiest and most tourist-friendly country in the peninsula. Not that one can now traverse the Musandam peninsula (exclave) using a new official crossing at Dibba Al Fujairah.

parameters.name: Pakistan
parameters.visa_comment:
To apply for the e-visa, visit the following website: https://visa.nadra.gov.pk/e-visa/welcome
Note that if you're in India, you'll have to use a VPN.

parameters.disputed: Breakaway Moldovan republic only recognized by Russia.
parameters.name: Transdniestria

translations.ja: 沿ドニエストル共和国

parameters.comment: One can visit only as part of a package tour and in public transport.
parameters.name: North Korea

translations.ja: 朝鮮民主主義人民共和国

parameters.disputed: Israel does not recognize Palestinian independence and maintains administrative control over the territory's borders.
parameters.name: Palestine
Sahrawi Republic
parameters.visa_comment:
The Polisario Front control the territory east of the "berm", a sand barricade built by the Moroccans. West of the berm, the territory is controlled by Morocco, where it's called "Southern Provinces". Talking about "Western Sahara" in Morocco is frowned upon.
So there is no visa to enter the region controlled by the Sahrawi, but you need an authorization from the Algerian government to cross the border.
parameters.disputed: Also known as Western Sahara, this is not an internationally recognized state. It is claimed by Morocco, although the UN doesn't recognize its sovereignty.

translations.zh: 撒拉威阿拉伯民主共和國
translations.ja: サハラ・アラブ民主共和国

parameters.name: Saudi Arabia
parameters.comment:
The country was tightly closed down until 2019. It's now very easy to get into the country with an e-visa and no carnet requirement (although surrounding countries require one).
Al Ula is now the only place having a solid tourist infrastructure, with the pharaonic NEOM project still in contruction, but the rest of the country is very welcoming nonetheless.
Note that the immediate border area with Yemen and Oman are forbidden, and the Mecca city access is restrited to Muslims. The rest of the country is free.
parameters.carnet_comment: Carnet isn't required or asked for. If you manage to have it stamped the vehicle can stay up to 6 months. Otherwise 3 months, legally, although it seems this isn't enforced at the border.
parameters.visa_comment:
Most countries are eligible to an e-visa. It's done online, very easy and fast: https://visa.visitsaudi.com. 
Visa is valid for 90 days (multiple entries) within 1 year of getting the visa. You can re-apply for a new visa only after 1 year.
Price (2025) about 385 SAR, it includes a mandatory health insurance.
Just show your passport at the border, if you have bought the e-visa online, it will show up on their computer and they will let you go (no stamp in the passport).
If you don't have a visa, and if you're eligible, you can also buy the visa at the border, it's the same price but it takes a little more time.
Note that your entry in the country is only recorded in the computer system, there is no entry or exit stamp (or visa) physically in your passport.

parameters.name: Senegal
parameters.carnet_comment: A carnet is necessary only for vehicles older than 5 years; otherwise a passe-avant (TIP) is enough.

parameters.comment: The road tax system makes this tiny country far too expensive to visit with a vehicle.
parameters.name: Singapore

countries.name: S. Geo. and S. Sandw. Is.

parameters.name: S. Geo. and S. Sandw. Is.

parameters.disputed: Unrecognized but de facto independent state, formerly part of Somalia.
parameters.name: Somaliland

parameters.comment: The country will be unsafe for the foreseeable future.
parameters.name: Somalia
South Ossetia
parameters.comment:
It's possible to visit the country from the Russia side, but only if you get prior authorization.
Crossing from Georgia is impossible.
Since the 2008 war between Russia and Georgia, Georgia has lost all sovereignty of South Ossetia and Russia, which recognizes it as a sovereign state, has control over its security.
parameters.disputed: Breakaway Georgian republic only recognized by Russia and a few other states.

parameters.name: Suriname
parameters.visa_comment: Only country of South America to require a visa (for Europeans, Americans have a harder time with regard to visas anyway).

parameters.comment: The situation is not stable yet, enquire about the current regulations before trying to enter.
parameters.name: Syria

parameters.capital: กรุงเทพมหานคร
parameters.name: Thailand
parameters.carnet_comment:
No carnet is needed. Instead, one needs a Foreign Vehicle Permit (FVP), which can only be obtained through a registered travel agency.
The problem is that it costs upward of 500$.
Easiest way to get it in advance: 
https://fvpthailand.com/

parameters.name: Tajikistan
parameters.carnet_comment: Temporary import permit limited to 15 days. You can extend it by visiting the customs office at any border post.
parameters.comment: Note: you need a so-called GBAO permit to visit the east of the country, the Pamir. If you stay in Dushanbe or in the Fan mountains in the west, no permit is required.
parameters.visa_comment:
Most European and Western countries can enter visa-free for 30 days. But in this case, you'll need to procure a GBAO permit by yourself, in Dushanbe. You also need to register to the authorities within 10 days (best done through a hotel).
You can also easily get an e-visa online.
In this case, you can order the GBAO permit with the visa.

parameters.carnet_comment: No carnet required but an escort is needed, except with a transit visa (3-5 days max)
parameters.name: Turkmenistan
parameters.visa_comment: The famous 5-days transit visa, which allowed to cross the country on their own, isn't available anymore, so the only other solution is the normal tourist visa, which comes with strings attached: you need a guide to accompany you all the time, so it's very expensive.
parameters.comment:
On of the most interesting of the former USSR republics, with a lot of reminiscences of the former dictatorship.
Note: the famous Darvaza crater that was burning gas has ben put out in 2025, so there isn't much to see nowadays, unfortunately.
The South-East corner of the country is definitely a no-go, but the rest of the country can be visited without any problem.
parameters.name: Ukraine

parameters.comment: Getting fuel may be problematic in some remote parts of the country, especially near Kazakhstan where petrol stations are frequently out of fuel.
parameters.name: Uzbekistan
parameters.visa_comment:
Citizens from most European countries can enter visa-free for up to 30 days.
Otherwise, the 30-days e-visa costs 20$. 
Note that you're required to register at OVIR within 3 days of entering the country. It is best done by your hotel manager, so if you're camping, you'll have to do it yourself.

translations.fr: État de la Cité du Vatican

parameters.carnet_comment: No foreign-registered vehicle can enter Vietnam
parameters.comment: Foreign vehicles are banned from the country.
parameters.name: Vietnam
Yemen
parameters.visa_comment: Visas are granted through a travel agency only, and basically only together with a package tour to the island of Soccotra.
parameters.comment:
The whole north-west area around Sana'a and the saudi border is very unsafe. The east of the country is supposed to be stable, but still very difficult to get it.
The small island of Soccotra, which is part of Yemen, is safe and is the only place tourists can routinely visit, but only through a travel agency and by flying in from Abu Dhabi or Cairo.

parameters.carnet_comment: A carnet is required only if you're shipping into the country, not when entering through a land border
parameters.name: South Africa
Zimbabwe
parameters.visa_comment: Get the e-visa at: https://www.evisa.gov.zw/
